timeline.bodyText: is there an edge case this is intended to test that testPut doesn't cover?
timeline.author: bkonold

replies.bodyText: Yes, this tests when the value has zero length. testPut is puts a non-empty value.
replies.author: cameronlee314

replies.bodyText: Sorry should have been more clear. What code path is this testing that testPut isn't? Does the implementation behave differently when the length is 0?
replies.author: bkonold

replies.bodyText: With the current implementation, it doesn't test a different code path. It just seemed like an edge case that would be good to cover.
replies.author: cameronlee314

timeline.bodyText:
doesn't this assume that key(0) and value(0) lengths are the same as key(i) and value(i) from the loop? can we re-write this so it more obviously matches the 10 writes that happen in the loop or add a comment indicating this assumption? or perhaps define a constant that represents the length of an integer key / value... just to make this more readable.
same comment applies to other occurrences of loops in your tests
timeline.author: bkonold

replies.bodyText: Yep, it does assume that, good point. Thanks for the suggestion. I defined a constant and added some more javadocs to clarify this.
replies.author: cameronlee314

timeline.bodyText: ty for noting the bug; will make it easy to fix when tests fail once the bug is fixed
